messages.text: Getting a `HTTP.ExceptionRequest.StatusError` when deploying docs, and I cannot figure whether the issue is with Plots, Literate, Documenter, another package, or my code. Please help! Details in thread!

elements.text: when deploying docs, and I cannot figure whether the issue is with Plots, Literate, Documenter, another package, or my code. Please help! Details in thread!

messages.text: So the issue is in <https://github.com/JuliaOcean/AIBECS.jl/pull/65/checks?check_run_id=2274261157#step:5:80|this PR preview docs> that was triggered by Compat Helper. Attached is the relevant portion of the stack trace. It looks like an HTTP.jl issue, but I am at a loss as to why that would be. The rest of the stacktrace just metions Literate.jl, which I'm not sure how to interpret either. FWIW, the cell that throws is a simple heatmap-type of recipes that worked perfectly fine before, and that cell comes after a bunch of fairly similar calls. Any help / pointers would be much appreciated! :pray:

messages.text:
Problem when attempt to have an Float64-array with specified amount of possible states.
```Array = rand(Float64, Parameters["Population_size"], Parameters["Genes"])
AF_Array = AFArray(Array)```
This works quite well, but problem is, that there must be x-states for values. When I code:
```Array = rand(0:Max_state, Parameters["Population_size"], Parameters["Genes"])
AF_Array = AFArray(Array)```
This gives an Int64-array, but when I try to decode it to an float-array 0..1 at another function:
```Decoded = Feed / Max_state```
Becomes problem, due "Decoded" wants to be an Int64-array and is filled with zeros, when it should be Float64-array.

How to fix it..? :thinking_face:

This gives an Int64-array, but when I try to decode it to an float-array 0..1 at another function:

How to fix it..?

messages.text: Hi, a question on `SparseMatrixCSC` . I have a code (a solver for linear systems) which should have quasilinear complexity in solving linear systems. Unfortunately I have one bottleneck which is extracting submatrices `A[i,j]` from the big sparse matrix. This should be an O(n log n) operation but it seems that the current implementation is infuriatingly slow and O(n^2). I have found some closed threads on discourse but it is unclear what the current status is on that. Any hints?

elements.text: . I have a code (a solver for linear systems) which should have quasilinear complexity in solving linear systems. Unfortunately I have one bottleneck which is extracting submatrices

from the big sparse matrix. This should be an O(n log n) operation but it seems that the current implementation is infuriatingly slow and O(n^2). I have found some closed threads on discourse but it is unclear what the current status is on that. Any hints?

messages.text: Is there anything harmful or discouraged about using `Base.remove_linenums!` inside a macro?

elements.text: Is there anything harmful or discouraged about using

messages.text: The downside is that it might make errors harder to pinpoint

elements.text: The downside is that it might make errors harder to pinpoint

messages.text:
For example,
```julia> macro identity(ex)
           esc(Base.remove_linenums!(ex))
       end
@identity (macro with 1 method)

julia> @identity begin
           x = 1 + 1
           y = 2x + "hi"
       end
ERROR: MethodError: no method matching +(::Int64, ::String)
Stacktrace:
 [1] top-level scope
   @ REPL[10]:1```

elements.text:
julia> macro identity(ex)
           esc(Base.remove_linenums!(ex))
       end
@identity (macro with 1 method)

julia> @identity begin
           x = 1 + 1
           y = 2x + "hi"
       end
ERROR: MethodError: no method matching +(::Int64, ::String)
Stacktrace:
 [1] top-level scope
   @ REPL[10]:1

messages.text:
Versus
```julia> begin
           x = 1 + 1
           y = 2x + "hi"
       end
ERROR: MethodError: no method matching +(::Int64, ::String)
Stacktrace:
 [1] top-level scope
   @ REPL[11]:3```
This one tells you it was line 3 in the input that produced the error

elements.text:
julia> begin
           x = 1 + 1
           y = 2x + "hi"
       end
ERROR: MethodError: no method matching +(::Int64, ::String)
Stacktrace:
 [1] top-level scope
   @ REPL[11]:3
This one tells you it was line 3 in the input that produced the error

messages.text:
Hey I'm not sure if this is possible or advisable but I'm trying to use the type system to let me define addition on some custom functions by delayed application. For example
```function add(n)
    function adder(v)
        v + n
    end
end

function +(a::??,b::??)
    x -> a(v) + b(v) ::??
end```
So that the following would hold
```(add(2) + add(3))(4) == add(2)(4) + add(3)(4) == 6 + 7 == 13```
I don't understand how the type system works for functions in Julia.
I suppose I could put the data in add into a struct, define addition over the struct and create a
function which then implements the addition (in this example) on some input,
but it would be much more convenient if something like what Ive written was possible.

messages.text:
On OSX 10.15.7 I have problems with any package that evokes the FFMPEG.jl, e.g. making a recording w/ Javis.jl or Makie.jl. Any thoughts?
```record(figure, "f16.mkv", 1:100; framerate = 10) do trans
           GLMakie.translate!(obj, trans)
       end
dyld: Library not loaded: @rpath/libbz2.1.0.6.dylib
  Referenced from: /Users/me/.julia/artifacts/c28cdc80b48b1077c8fc57d8e94e6eb9c1a4a776/bin/ffmpeg
  Reason: Incompatible library version: ffmpeg requires version 1.0.0 or later, but libbz2.1.0.6.dylib provides version 0.0.0
ERROR: LoadError: IOError: write: broken pipe (EPIPE)```
If I `./ ffmpeg`  or the artifact directly I get
```dyld: Library not loaded: @rpath/libass.9.dylib
  Referenced from: /Users/me/.julia/artifacts/c28cdc80b48b1077c8fc57d8e94e6eb9c1a4a776/bin/./ffmpeg
  Reason: image not found```

attachments.title: How Do I Most Effectively Use Multiple Dispatch in Data Science Workflows?
attachments.text: Hi all, Say if I have two DataFrames: df1 and df2. They have unique values but have the same column names: Cost, Customer, and Product. As I move forward with my data processing, sometimes, I want to harmonize the DataFrames using the Customer and Cost via a join and then run a specific set of analyses for this harmonization. Other times, I want to harmonize the DataFrames across Customer and Product via a join and run a different set of analyses. What would be the best approach to handle diffe...

end```

messages.text:
Hi everyone, I was looking through `base/bitarrays.jl` and had a question about a part of the code:
What is does `::$T` represent in this part of the code?
```for (T, f) in ((:(Union{typeof(&), typeof(*), typeof(min)}), :(&)),
               (:(Union{typeof(|), typeof(max)}),            :(|)),
               (:(Union{typeof(xor), typeof(!=)}),           :xor),
               (:(typeof(nand)),                             :nand),
               (:(typeof(nor)),                             :nor),
               (:(Union{typeof(>=), typeof(^)}),             :((p, q) -> p | ~q)),
               (:(typeof(<=)),                               :((p, q) -> ~p | q)),
               (:(typeof(==)),                               :((p, q) -> ~xor(p, q))),
               (:(typeof(<)),                                :((p, q) -> ~p & q)),
               (:(typeof(>)),                                :((p, q) -> p & ~q)))
    ## Question Here
    @eval map(::$T, A::BitArray, B::BitArray) = bit_map!($f, similar(A), A, B)
    @eval map!(::$T, dest::BitArray, A::BitArray, B::BitArray) = bit_map!($f, dest, A, B)
end```
I understand the purpose of `@eval`  and `$`, but I don’t understand what the `::` is doing here without a variable name in front of it. Thanks!

is doing here without a variable name in front of it. Thanks!

messages.text:
```mydict = Dict('a'=>1,'b'=>1)
mydict['a'] 
mydict = Dict(:a=>1,:b=>"v")
mydict[:a]```
I understand that I am using symbol to access the value in the 2nd approach. But I am wondering what are the fundamental difference between these two approaches? When should I chose one over another. Thanks!

messages.text: I know that I can generate a random variable using `rand(-1:0.01:1)` . Is there any convenience function built in Julia that allows me to call the same function multiple times and returns a list of number returned from each call?

can an unregistered package not be used as a test dep, without being a dep? (only in extras, not [deps])
```┌ Warning: Could not use exact versions of packages in manifest, re-resolving
└ @ Pkg.Operations /buildworker/worker/package_linux64/build/usr/share/julia/stdlib/v1.6/Pkg/src/Operations.jl:1524
ERROR: expected package `SBMLBioModelsRepository [f8843788]` to be registered```
this is the extras of proj.toml
```[extras]
SBMLBioModelsRepository = "f8843788-970d-48f8-85db-cbc3f4864f31"
Test = "8dfed614-e22c-5e08-85e1-65c5234f0b40"

[targets]
test = ["Test", "SBMLBioModelsRepository"]```

messages.text: We observe something really strange in HypothesisTests.jl: tests passed on Travis CI on both Julia 1.0.5 and 1.5 in November. No commit has been pushed since then, but now that I tried moving to GitHub Actions, tests fail on 1.0.5 and 1.6 with the same error (p-values very different from expected values). I also get this error locally on 1.0.5 and 1.6. What can possibly explain this difference? :confused:

elements.text: We observe something really strange in HypothesisTests.jl: tests passed on Travis CI on both Julia 1.0.5 and 1.5 in November. No commit has been pushed since then, but now that I tried moving to GitHub Actions, tests fail on 1.0.5 and 1.6 with the same error (p-values very different from expected values). I also get this error locally on 1.0.5 and 1.6. What can possibly explain this difference?

messages.text: See <https://github.com/JuliaStats/HypothesisTests.jl/pull/229> and e.g. <https://travis-ci.com/github/JuliaStats/HypothesisTests.jl/jobs/430505929>.

I am trying to understand Julia syntax. For example, in this code, `_using_ Colors; Colors.colorant"red"` I am trying to understand the `colorant"red"` part. Can anybody explain the Julia syntax at work here? Is this a function call / constant lookup / string? I am more accustomed to seeing `colorant(red)` from other programming languages, and the placement of double quote is very bizarre to me.
